channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kim Jong-un Invites South Korean Leader to North for Summit Meeting
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, third from right, meeting on Saturday with Kim Yo-jong, second from left, in Seoul with other officials. Ms. Kim relayed an invitation from her brother, Kim Jong-un, to Mr. Moon.
item.description: After North Korea’s leader relayed the proposal through his sister, President Moon Jae-in said the Koreas should “create the environment to make it happen.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Israel Attacks Targets in Syria After Iranian Drone Enters Israeli Airspace and Jet Crashes
item.media:description: A picture taken in northern Israel on Saturday purports to show the remains of an Israeli F-16 that crashed after coming under Syrian antiaircraft fire.
item.description: Israel said it had launched a major attack after its F-16 came under Syrian fire. The events appeared to be Israel’s first direct engagement with Iranian forces in the Golan Heights.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: In Paris Terrorism Trial, a Protest of Few Words
item.media:description: Sven Mary, the Belgian lawyer representing Salah Abdeslam, speaking outside court in Brussels on Thursday. Mr. Abdeslam is suspected of carrying out terrorist attacks in Paris in 2015 and Brussels in 2016.
item.description: At trial in Belgium, Salah Abdeslam refuses to answer questions from the judge as a way of protesting European justice, defense lawyers say.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: As Britain Stumbles Over Brexit, Support Grows for 2nd Vote
item.media:description: Protesters waving European Union flags gathered in Cardiff, Wales, last month at a site where a pro-Brexit event was supposed to take place.
item.media:credit: Jim Wood/SOPA Images, via Getty Images
item.description: As the Tories struggle to negotiate Britain’s departure from the bloc, and business leaders issue alarms about the threats to the economy, calls for another referendum gain momentum.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Worries Rise as Pope and China Edge Closer to Deal on Bishops
item.media:description: Mass was celebrated on Holy Saturday during Easter celebrations at the government-sanctioned West Beijing Catholic Church in China last year.
item.description: A crucial issue is who gets to appoint the bishops and whether Rome will have a say. A retired archbishop of Hong Kong fears the Vatican is “selling out” Chinese Catholics.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Oxfam, British Charity, Admits Sexual Misconduct by Workers in Haiti
item.media:description: A latrine project led and financed by Oxfam for displaced Haitians living in Port-au-Prince in 2011.
item.description: A newspaper reported that Oxfam officials hired prostitutes and held sex parties in 2011. The group fired four people and three quit under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Colombian Rebels Suspend Election Campaign, Putting Peace Into Limbo
item.media:description: Protesters disrupted a campaign rally held this week for Rodrigo Londoño, the former wartime leader of the FARC rebel group and currently a presidential candidate in Colombia.
item.description: The largest rebel group, the FARC, has suspended campaigning in the coming elections, saying its candidates have been attacked and are unsafe.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: She Won Italians’ Hearts. But Can She Win Their Votes?
item.media:description: Emma Bonino, center, at a news conference last year. Ms. Bonino enjoys high approval ratings, but that hasn’t always translated into votes.
item.description: Respected for her civil rights battles, Emma Bonino’s slogan in the Italian parliamentary election is “Love Me Less, Vote Me More.”
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Olympics Open With Koreas Marching Together, Offering Hope for Peace
item.media:description: The unified Korean team marching in the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics at Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The détente between North and South transcended several other compelling story lines, including the participation of Russian athletes despite a doping scandal.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Fight Over Cambodian Leader’s Facebook ‘Likes’ Reaches a U.S. Court
item.media:description: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia, center, in Phnom Penh this month.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: An opposition politician argues that Hun Sen, the Asian country’s authoritarian premier, has used social media to spread fake news and strengthen his hold on power.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE

item.title: A Murder Trial Stirs Emotions About Canada’s Relations With Indigenous Population
item.media:description: Supporters of Colton Boushie’s family outside the court in Battleford, Saskatchewan, Canada, on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.description: Some in a Saskatchewan town question how much progress has been made in Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s effort at reconciliation with the First Nations of Canada.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Greek Politicians May Have Taken Bribes from Drug Maker, Prosecutors Say
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Antonis Samaras is one of the 10 the politicians accused in the bribery inquiry. Mr. Samaras said the allegations amounted to the “most ruthless and ridiculous conspiracy ever.”
item.description: The inquiry, which was sent to Parliament by prosecutors on Tuesday, is centered on accusations from three people who are believed to be Novartis employees.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Door Opens for Women to Run for Office. But Will They Be Allowed In?
item.media:description: The Sri Lankan Parliament in Colombo in October. Women make up more than half of registered voters in the country, but there are very few in elected office.
item.description: Sri Lanka has introduced a 25 percent quota for female candidates in local elections, but many have faced abuse, and obstructionism within their own parties.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Reuters Publishes Account of Myanmar Massacre After Journalists’ Arrests
item.media:description: A photograph said to show 10 Rohingya Muslims before their execution in September last year. The news agency Reuters has published a detailed account of the events.
item.description: The news agency used photos and witness accounts to describe the killings of 10 Rohingya men. Two reporters who worked on the article were charged with obtaining state secrets.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: In China’s Coal Country, a Ban Brings Blue Skies, Cold Homes
item.media:description: A black market coal store in Qiaoli, China. The nearby city of Linfen was once one of the world’s most heavily polluted cities.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: Seeking cleaner skies, China is moving aggressively to reduce its dependence of coal. This environmentalism from above has had problems and successes.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: What Are the Biggest Olympic Events? It Depends on Where You Are
item.media:description: South Korean and North Korean short-track speedskaters trained Friday in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The event is the most popular Olympic sport in this year’s host nation, South Korea.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: A sport that might raise a yawn in one country will rivet audiences in another.
item.dc:creator: VICTOR MATHER

item.title: Tragedy for a Residential School Survivor, and the ‘Real’ Olympics Begin: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Verna Denny, a former residential school student whose grandson, Colten Boushie, was shot and killed on a farm in 2016.
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.description: This week’s Canada Letter looks at a murder case that has divided Saskatchewan and previews The Times’s Winter Olympics coverage.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: The Pope and China: Why It’s Complicated
item.description: Pope Francis is considering giving the Chinese government a say in the Vatican’s ordination of bishops in the country. Not everyone in the Catholic Church is cheering.

item.title: John Kelly, Winter Games, Flu: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Swedish Bookseller Held in China Surfaces for Video Apology
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong last year with pictures of Gui Minhai, third from left, and of other missing booksellers.
item.description: Gui Minhai, the bookseller who was snatched from a train last month, gave an interview at a detention center that appeared to have been coerced.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Daylight Saving Time: What’s It Good For? European Lawmakers Ask
item.media:description: A worker at sunrise in Pamplona, Spain, last month. Daylight saving time was first introduced in Europe and the United States after World War I as part of an effort to conserve energy and decrease the use of fuel for lighting and heating.
item.description: Members of the European Parliament have joined the chorus of skeptics who argue that changing the clocks does more harm than good and should be revised.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Nanny Who Set Fatal Fire in China Is Sentenced to Death
item.media:description: Mo Huanjing listening to her sentence in a court in Hangzhou, China, on Friday. The fire she started killed three children and their mother; she had hoped to be rewarded for rescuing them.
item.media:credit: Hangzhou Intermediate People's Court, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The blaze killed the three children Mo Huanjing was caring for, and their mother. Her case has prompted a debate about trust, greed and inequality.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and IRIS ZHAO

item.title: Sister of North Korean Leader Arrives in South Korea for Highly Symbolic Trip
item.media:description: Kim Yo-jong, sister of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, at Incheon International Airport in South Korea on Friday with Kim Yong-nam, right, the North’s nominal head of state. At left is South Korea’s unification minister, Cho Myoung-gyon.
item.description: Her three-day trip is to include a meeting with President Moon Jae-in, the highest-level inter-Korean contact in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Tumultuous Week on Wall Street Ends With a Small Rally
item.media:description: A display outside a securities firm in Tokyo showed Friday morning’s stock market drop.
item.description: Stocks gyrated through the day, but ended on an upswing, about 1.4 percent higher. In global markets, Chinese stocks were among the biggest casualties.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FLITTER and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: How We Achieved an Olympic Feat of Immersive Journalism
item.media:description: View of figure skater Nathan Chen in AR.
item.description: The Times’s newsroom, design and product staffs collaborated to bring Olympic athletes, at scale and midperformance, into your living room.
item.dc:creator: GRAHAM ROBERTS

item.title: Bermuda Outlaws Gay Marriage, Less Than a Year After It Became Legal
item.media:description: Tourists in St. George’s, Bermuda, in 2015.
item.description: The British overseas territory adopted a domestic partnership law, instead, but gay rights advocates dismissed it as a “separate-but-equal” measure.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Ethiopia to Free 746 Prisoners
item.description: Among the prisoners to be freed are a journalist and a senior opposition official who were jailed for conspiracy to commit terrorist acts, the attorney general’s office said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Winter Games, Syria, Rob Porter: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: North Korean Orchestra Gives an Emotional Concert in the South
item.media:description: The North Korean Samjiyon Orchestra performing in Gangneung, South Korea, on Thursday.
item.description: Musicians played K-pop, Mozart, Josh Groban and other popular hymns. For some in the audience, it was their first time seeing North Koreans.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: The Quiet Diplomacy to Save the Olympics in a Nuclear Standoff
item.media:description: A visiting North Korean band leaving a welcoming ceremony for the country’s Olympic athletes in Gangneung, South Korea, on Thursday.
item.description: Organizers worried that the North would spoil the Winter Games in Pyeongchang. But after months of anxiety and failed diplomacy, there was a deal.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ, CHOE SANG-HUN and REBECCA R. RUIZ

item.title: Winter Olympics’ Security on Alert, but Hackers Have a Head Start
item.description: Some computer systems connected to the 2018 Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea, have already been compromised, experts said. The big question is what happens next.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: 2 of ISIS’ Infamous British Fighters Are Captured by Syrian Kurds
item.media:description: A member of the American-backed Syrian Democratic Forces in October inside a prison built by Islamic State fighters in Raqqa, Syria. The group is said to have detained two Britons infamous for their role in torturing Westerners.
item.description: The men were part of a notorious group of Islamic State militants known as the Beatles because of their British accents.
item.dc:creator: ADAM GOLDMAN and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Art Looted by Nazis Gets a New Space at the Louvre. But Is It Really Home?
item.media:description: Paintings looted or bought by German occupiers during World War II were recently put on display together at the Louvre in Paris.
item.description: The museum is displaying the work in two new rooms. Critics praise the effort but say it does little to reunite the paintings with their rightful owners.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: It’s Hard to Believe, but Syria’s War Is Getting Even Worse
item.media:description: A Syrian Civil Defense member carrying a wounded child in the besieged town of Hamoria, in Eastern Ghouta, last month.
item.description: The conflict has broken into several small wars, and the carnage is reaching a new peak, upending any assumptions it might be nearing an end.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Netanyahu Lashes Out as Israeli Police Wrap Up Graft Inquiries
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with his wife, Sara, in Davos, Switzerland, in January. He faces two corruption investigations.
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused a police chief of “mendacious” insinuations against him. Critics say he is trying to discredit the investigations.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: South China Sea Photos Suggest a Military Building Spree by Beijing
item.media:description: Subi (Zamora) Reef in November.
item.description: China has spent years establishing military outposts on a group of contested islands in the South China Sea. New photos offered a detailed look.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and MIKKO TAKKUNEN
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: What South Koreans Really Think of the Olympic Thaw
item.media:description: South Koreans holding “unification flags” at a hockey game between South Korea and North Korea in 2017. The two Koreas will have a joint women’s hockey team at the Games.
item.description: One reader said it was humiliating that South Korea was not marching under its own flag. Another said her grandfather might see his North Korean family again.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by KELLY VIRELLA

item.title: Upgraded Designs Unveiled for Road Tunnel Near Stonehenge
item.media:description: Stonehenge draws hundreds of thousands of visitors each year.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The aim is to upgrade a highway in the county of Wiltshire, in southwest England, to address concerns that the landscape could be scarred and irreparably damaged.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Chengdu Journal: First Rule of Chinese Fight Club: No Karaoke
item.media:description: A fight club in Chengdu, China, which goes by the English name “Monster Private War Club.”
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: In Chengdu, the owners of the “Monster Private War Club” want to make fighting cool. But to stay open, they also need to keep it respectable.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: Iran Plays Down Report That U.S. Secretly Asked for Talks on Prisoners
item.media:description: Babak Namazi spoke at a news conference in Vienna in April. His father, Baquer Namazi, pictured left, and his brother Siamak, right, were convicted by an Iranian court in 2016 of collaborating with a hostile power.
item.description: The American inquiries were rejected, an official in Tehran said. “They have shown themselves as dishonest,” he added, “so what is the use of new talks?”
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: U.S.-Backed Coalition in Syria Strikes Pro-Assad Forces
item.media:description: United States Air Force jets flying above Syria this month.
item.media:credit: Colton Elliott/U.S Department of Defense, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Americans say the coalition repelled an attack by forces backing President Bashar al-Assad in a rare confrontation between groups that have both fought ISIS.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Rising Hummus Prices? Blame a Drought Half a World Away
item.media:description: Limited supplies of chickpeas have combined with rising demand for hummus in Britain to send prices there 12 percent higher than a year ago.
item.media:credit: Craig Lee for The New York Times
item.description: Poor crops of chickpeas in India have made the dish more expensive in British supermarkets, the latest example of extreme weather affecting global food prices.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: South Korean Leader to Meet Kim Jong-un’s Sister in Highest-Level Contact in Years
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea at an International Olympic Committee meeting in Gangneung on Monday.
item.description: In North Korea’s dynastic system, Kim Jong-un’s sister, Kim Yo-jong, wields clout that cannot be matched by any other member of the political elite.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: International Criminal Court Will Investigate Duterte Over Drug War
item.media:description: A complaint filed to the International Criminal Court calls President Rodrigo Duterte the “mastermind” of a campaign of extrajudicial killings in the Philippines.
item.description: The Hague-based tribunal said it would gauge whether there was enough evidence to build a case against the Philippine president for crimes against humanity.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Norovirus Cases at Olympics More Than Double, Moving Beyond Security Staff
item.media:description: A security point at the Gangneung Olympic Park on Wednesday. The highly contagious norovirus has spread beyond the security personnel who were the first known to have contracted it.
item.description: The number of cases has risen to 86, and the virus may be traveling quickly across other Olympic areas.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Two Koreas, Split by War, Use Olympics to Make Rare Shows of Unity
item.media:description: North and South Korea have formed a joint team in women’s ice hockey for the Pyeongchang Olympics. The combined squad played an exhibition match against Sweden on Sunday.
item.description: Despite clashes, North and South Korea have learned to use the Olympics to find something that still eludes them in the real world: a moment of solidarity.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
